Dear Red Sox Fans: Don’t Panic (Yet)

Jack Roche
Apr 1

Baseball season is officially back.

The reigning World Series champs are off to a sluggish start, sitting at 1–3 after a road series against the young Seattle Mariners. Manager Alex Cora even remarked that the Red Sox are “lucky” to have one win. Before Sox fans worry of a championship hangover, and before their competitors begin to rejoice, I urge everyone to take a step back and look at the positives.

Starting Pitching

Chris Sale will not finish the season with a 21.00 ERA. While fans may have concerns about Sale’s future given his recent 5-year, $145 million extension, this isn’t the beginning of the end. His fastball sat an average velocity of 92.3 miles per hour. We know Sale as a guy who can dial it up in the upper 90s if need be. Throughout the 2018 season, he threw his four-seam fastball at an average of 95.4 miles per hour. This drop may seem concerning, but manager Alex Cora isn’t worried.

“When I was the bench coach in Houston, a lot of people were saying he threw 99 from the get-go and ran out of bullets in October. So which one will you take? Him throwing 99 in March or April or him pitching in the World Series?” — Alex Cora

Last season, Sale dealt with shoulder injuries, allowing him to only pitch 158 innings. With this consideration, Sale’s velocity does tend to vary by month. His average fastball sat below 94 mph in each of his first seven starts last year. On the other end of the spectrum, his fastball was averaging over 97.1 mph in July before hitting the DL. Perhaps pacing is the key to Sale’s pursuit of a Cy Young award and postseason success. At this point in the season, don’t worry about Sale’s velocity. The command of his slider was shaky, but that has been the most lethal pitch in his arsenal. Sale is going to be just fine.

As for the rest of the rotation, what we’ve seen hasn’t been pretty. Porcello (2.2 IP, 4 ER), Eovaldi (5 IP, 6 ER), and Rodriguez (4.1 IP, 5 ER) all have an ERA above 10. This may be worrisome, but these are the same guys who had tremendous success on the way to the World Series last season. This rotation that had the 4th most strike-outs and 6th best ERA in 2018. Eovaldi might not replicate what we saw in the playoffs last year, but fans should give the rotation a few more games before freaking out.

The Bullpen

Through four games, we haven’t gotten the opportunity to see the bullpen on full display.

Matt Barnes closed the game in the Sox’s lone win, punching out 2. While this doesn’t mean that he is the closer from here on out, his performance has yet to give fans any doubts.

Ryan Brasier and Colten Brewer have both looked good in their small sample size. Brasier (1 IP, 0 ER, 2 Ks) and Brewer (2 IP, 0 ER, 4 Ks) will both compete with Barnes for the closer job. Thus far, all three candidates have been solid.

We don’t know the identity of this bullpen yet. We will know within a few weeks if one of these guys is cut out for the job or if Dombrowski will have to make a move to strengthen the ‘pen.

The Lineup

The Red Sox offense is still red-hot. They have averaged 6 runs a game, good for 6th best in the MLB. J.D. Martinez has picked up right where he left off in 2018, going 7/17 with 2 HRs and 7 RBIs. Rafael Devers, who has appeared in the 3-hole twice, has raked as well (6/17, 2 2Bs). Mookie and Moreland have both added dingers.

While Benintendi and Bogaerts have combined for just 5 hits thus far, its hard to draw conclusions based on their performance last year and the current sample size given.

The lineup carried the team last year, scoring the most runs in the MLB. So far, they haven’t shown any signs of slowing down.

The Future

One of the hardest things to do is keep a title-contending team together. Sox fans should remain optimistic that their 108-win team is largely still together, now and for the future.

On Saturday, it was announced that Xander Bogaerts and the Red Sox had agreed to a 7-year extension. Bogey has been one of the best shortstops in the league for the past few seasons, and an integral part of the offense at just 26 years old. He joins Sale and Eovaldi as members of the World Series team to sign new contracts.

Yes, the Sox are off to a rough start. I know expectations are high for a team that put up historic numbers last season. However, I urge all Bostonians to wait until at least May to freak out.
